page.title: 11LOCAL HISTORY 10
page.content: The wells were first referred to in 1740 by Dr. Short of Sheffield and in 1760 it was noted that the clear spring water possessed the ability to cure 'scarbetic disorders and leprosy'. The two wells fell into disrepair but were restored in the early part of this century. A pavilion, tea rooms and bandstand were added. Caergwrle rock and spring water were sold. Other features which attracted tourists were the Castle, the fountain and pumphouse, and the Bridge Inn. {(Local history)} {(Recreation)}
